div.p: THE FOVRE SVMMONS OF THE SHVLAMITE.
A Sermon preached at Pauls Croſse vpon Rogation Sunday, the 5. of May. 1605.
By JOHN RAWLINSON, Bachelor of Divinitie, and fellow of Saint Iohns Colledge in Oxford.

p.hi: The morning commeth, and alſo the night. Jf yee will ſeeke, ſeeke: returne, and come.

div.p: Printed at Oxford by Ioſeph Barnes, and are to be ſold in Paules Church-yard at the ſigne of the Crowne, by Simon Waterſon, 1606.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p: IT was my purpoſe (Gentle Reader) that theſe my ſory labours ſhould rather haue ſlept in ſilēce, and ben buried in the Church-yard where firſt they were publiſht, then by a ſecond publicatiō (more publike) haue ſtoode to the mercie of many mercileſſe Cenſors.

Sure J am, it had ben my ſafer and ſurer way, to haue practiſed the policie of Antony in Tully, Cicer. orat. pro Cluen • . who woulde never make his pen publike-Notarie to his tongue, that if ought had at any time fallen from him ſuperfluous or impertinent, hee might ſafely denie that to haue ben ſpoken, which written hee could not ſo ſoundly warrant:

Eſpecially, conſidering the conditiō of theſe times: wherein VVriters, and
Readers are both too-blame. For as there is more than Gods plenty of writers, ſuch as are at Davids Dico ego opera mea Regi: Pſal. 45.1. before they can ſaie with David, Eructavit cor meum verbum bonum: More carefull to provide a vvorthy Patron for their worke, than a learned worke worthy the Patronage: and ſo combring the Preſſe with froathy & worthles Pamphlets, that had it voice, it would hideouſly roare and cry, like a man now almoſt preſſt to death: More weight; for the loue of god, more weight: more weight in your matter, but leſse of your paper. So is there a marveilous paucity of Readers, (ſuch as are wel & charitably affected;) inſomuch that fevve there are of the more ingenuous ſorte, Qui malint eloquendo culpam deprecari, Macrob. Sa • . l. 1.
quàm tacendo culpâ vacare: who had rather by divulging their endevors craue a curteous pardon; than by ſuppreſſing them be out of gunſhot of cavill & exception; the very quinteſſence of many mens learning being nothing but a
carping at other mens labors; and yet ſome of thoſe many ſuch, as I know had rather preach 20. Sermons, than print one, leaſt their filching and purloining ſhould be tracked and detected.
But the Reaſons that haue vvrought me, thus to venture vpon the ſharpe of this ages cenſure, are chiefly two;

One, The inceſſant importunity of friends, to whom J may ſay as Paulinus doth to his vpon like occaſion:Paul. epiſt. 9 ad Sulpit. Sever. Sibi imputet famem, qui pauperis amici forem pulſat, & promptuariū inane ſcrutatur. Let him thanke himſelfe, if hee be ſent away hungry, who knocks as the dore of his poore friend, and rifles his empty cupbord for victuals.

Another, The inſtant neceſſitie of theſe daies (theſe laſt, & evill daies) the ſores wherof run and ceaſe not, becauſe the ſinnes thereof cry, & ſtent not; that by a deepe and diligent conſideration of the many ſaving leſſons herein contained, the men of this generation may vnfeignedly and effectually turne from
their wicked waies, and ſo turne awaie from them, and from this whole Land the angry viols of Gods dreadfull vengeance, the dregs wherof elſe they are likely to ſucke vp.

Theſe (with other the like) reaſons, haue ſomuch the rather prevailed with me, becauſe I am for ſurety givē to vnderſtād, that there paſſe abroad for current, ſome maimed and diſmēbred copies, (ſuch as were curſorily taken frō my mouth) which J knowe not how far forth they may turne to my preiudice: And haue cauſed me to republiſh this Sermon,Ioan. 11.44 like a Lazarus rediuinus, newly riſen out of the graue of forgetfulnes, bound about not with napkins, but with paper-ſheets; to preach not Viuâ v • ce, with any liuelyhood of voice as before (which yet is the chiefe grace & verniſh of a Sermō) but with a dead & black letter: A killing letter to thoſe that will not turne, but a quickening letter to the penitent Conuert; That what then was ſounded forth in the
eares of a Great and Honorable aſſembly (the very confluence of the whole Land) may now ſubiect it ſelfe likewiſe to the eies, aſwell of the then abſent, as of thoſe that were preſent:Aug. tract. de Epicur. 〈◊〉 Stoic. ca. 2.
Vt neſcientes inſtruantur, ſcientes cōmoneātur: illi cognoſcant, illi recognoſcāt: that the ignorant may be inſtructed, the learned admoniſhed, that the one may learne what his duty is, the other recognize what he hath learned:
That what then was confined with in the ſpace of two houres, may now be Omnium horarum: A ſermon for every houre:

Laſtly, That what thē, (by the bleſſing of God) was thought fruitfull to many, may now (by the ſame bleſſing) become profitable to all. It ſhal then be thy part (Chriſtian Reader) (ſuch as it is) to take it in good part, naked, and (J think) Verbatìm as it was vttered: as imparted vnto thee to no worſe end, than to make thee partaker of that bleſſed aſpect, which is promiſed (& ſhould
alſo haue ben hādled) in the ſecond general part of my Text, had not the time intercepted my diſcourſe.

Now if any ſhal aſke (as in ſuch a world of Buſybodies, many of liklyhood will) what the reaſon might be, that albeit I ſerue a Right-worthily Great & eminent Father of the Church, the Lorde Biſhop of London, (ſole prop and pillar of my hopes and fortunes) to whome as (in parte) J owe to the very prime beginnings of that ſmal preferment which J haue (which ſince he hath alſo ſeconded by many gratious encouragments:) ſo J wholy vow 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , the very vtmoſt mite of my poore ſeruice: Yet J ſend forth this Sermon into the world, as our Savior did his diſciples,Mat. 10.10. ſine baculo et perâ: without either the ſtaffe of protection, or the ſcrip of dedication wherwith to beg patronage; My anſwere is ready, that as Minimum maximi maius est maximo minimi. The leaſt of that which is greateſt is more than the greateſt of
the leaſt: ſo the leaſt of his fauours is more then the greateſt of my deſarts: and to preſent his Greatnes with ſo ſmall a preſent, were but aſsem Elephanto dare: as J may ſay,Macrob. Sat. l. 2. c. 4. to giue a dodkin to a Monarch.
I haue therfore choſen rather to expoſe it as a poore patronleſſe Orphan, that ſo it may happily meet with many Patrons. Vide. Pag. 56. J am ſure one part of it hath already met with ſome.

Or if it proue ſo infortunate, to haue none to patronize it, yet my truſt is that God (the father of Orphans) will accept it,Pſal. 68.5. To whoſe bleſſed protection J commit both it and thee: as my ſelfe & al my ſtudies to thy godly and dayly prayers: reciprocally prayeng vnto God, for thee, and thy ſouls good.

closer.signed: Thine in the Lord, JOHN RAWLINSON.
